The identification, ordering and extensive supplementation of the fragments of leaves 9-11 ( – ) is facilitated largely by parallel texts from Sanskrit Buddhist literature. Thus a1-2 is relatively closely matched by the Sanskrit text as restored from fragments of Turfan mss. by 51, and a2 – b3 may be compared with a Sanskrit text, also restored from Turfan fragments by 54-55. The former of the two is a section of text that can be found repeatedly in the Buddhist Sanskrit-tradition, such as CPS 16.16, 17.13, 22.15, 27f.22, NidSa 20.17, ŚPrSū 111, BimbSū 143. The Sanskrit text mentioned by 53 deviates slightly from these as does the Chinese parallel having five commandments [pañcaśikṣāpadāni]; see 46-47. Beyond this a further parallel can be found, which surprisingly enough and except for a few minor deviations is remarkably close to the Tocharian text, and which therefore contributes greatly to supplementing our text here. It is a Tumšuqese Karmavācanā text (cf. 649-670; for further reading) which from line 12-62 conforms almost verbatim to a1 – a3. Further important supplementations are owed to the TB fragments and [[PK NS 175]]. Certain deviations are caused by the fact that in the various versions occasionally different groups of persons are addressed. Thus the Sanskrit parts, the Tumšuqese text and contain formulas directed at lay followers (male, not female, as wrongly identified by 9ff), while our text here contains directives for novices. The small fragment [[PK NS 175]] does not allow for any closer designation in this respect.

The text of the first five commandments of the Tocharian version could be largely completed with the help of the Skt. text supplied in 54f, as well as – at least for commandments 1-3 – that of the Tumšuqese KaVā text. As for commandments 6-10, the Indic parallel versions (such as the Bhikṣukarmavākya, which belongs to the Mūlasarvāstivādin school) offer no more than mere lists of offences. For the Chinese Sarvāstivādin version cf. and 14, 570ff. When one compares the Tocharian version with the Sanskrit text from the Bhikṣukarmavākya (p. 21) and the Pāli text from the Mahāvagga (I.56) the following picture emerges:

tsaipeṃ śarka ploriyaṃ yetweṃ lkātsi yale based on the Sanskrit parallel (see above) the following correspondence could be established : Skt. nṛtya- "dance", : Skt. gīta- "singing, song, poem", : Skt. vādita- "instrumental music". According to : q.v. ploriyo* is an instrument, according to 188ff. specifically a wind instrument (possibly a flute). The concrete meaning "instrument" seemingly found in other passages and the more abstract meaning "instrumental music" in the given context can easily be reconciled if Tocharian ploriyo* and BHS vādita- had the same range of meaning as Classical Skt. vāditra-, namely, "musical instrument; instrumental music" (902-c). Similarly, it seems that śarka not only means "lute" (174ff.), but in the present context also more generally refers to "song". The other possibility is that śarka and ploriyo together refer to - lute and flute - music as partes pro toto; cf. b1, and a3 where we also have a collocation of śarka and ploriyo. 124 and 127 interprets "ornament, decoration" as equivalent of Pāli visūka- "show" (see above). In this case the meaning of yetwe (which also corresponds to Skt. anuvyañjana- "minor mark, characteristic") could be more generally understood as "characterisation", in the context of the commandment thus with the reading of "act of characterisation", i.e. "show, performance".

div.p: tsaipeṃ śarka ploriyaṃ yetweṃ lkātsi yale "go to see dancing, singing, instrumental music [and] shows [lit. ornaments]" corresponds to Pāli nacca-gīta-vādita-visūkadassana (Mahāvagga I.56) "dancing, singing, instrumental music, visiting shows" and Skt. nṛtta-gīta-vāditād (56, 15.7) "dancing, singing, instrumental music".
The following passage corresponds to the Skt. text in 55, 14.5 (note that the equivalent of Skt. upāsaka- "lay follower" is Toch. ṣanmīre "novice"):
TB: se takāsta ṣanmīre – – – – (ṣe)c(a)keṃts[e] e[n](äṣälyñene) /// [a gap of nine akṣaras] /// [p]p·[t] amāskai krentaunants (y)āt(a)ly(ñ)e ||

Skt.: eṣo ‘si upāsakaḥ | śākya-siṃhasya śāsana ārādhayasva mā virādhaya durlabhāḥ kṣaṇa-saṃpadāḥ || "You are now a lay follower. Be successful in the commandment of the Śākya-lion. Do not neglect the luck of the moment which is hard to attain."

krentaunants (y)āt(a)ly(ñ)e “power of virtues” presupposes guṇasaṃpadām (or °padāḥ) in the Skt. model, while Härtel reads kṣaṇasaṃpadaḥ (ms. form = °padāḥ) “the luck of the moment”. kṣaṇasaṃpad, according to , entry kṣaṇa-, “the good luck of (this) favourable birth”.

b3f. The following passage corresponds to the Skt. text in [[Härtel 1956]]: 55, 14.5 (note that the equivalent of Skt. upāsaka- "lay follower" is Toch. ṣanmīre "novice"):

TB: se takāsta ṣanmīre – – – – (ṣe)c(a)keṃts[e] e[n](äṣälyñene) /// [a gap of nine akṣaras] /// [p]p·[t] amāskai krentaunants (y)āt(a)ly(ñ)e ||

Skt.: eṣo ‘si upāsakaḥ | śākya-siṃhasya śāsana ārādhayasva mā virādhaya durlabhāḥ kṣaṇa-saṃpadāḥ ||
"You are now a lay follower. Be successful in the commandment of the Śākya-lion. Do not neglect the luck of the moment which is hard to attain."

b4. krentaunants (y)āt(a)ly(ñ)e “power of virtues” presupposes guṇasaṃpadām (or °padāḥ) in the Skt. model, while Härtel reads kṣaṇasaṃpadaḥ (ms. form = °padāḥ) “the luck of the moment”. kṣaṇasaṃpad, according to [[Edgerton BHSD]], entry kṣaṇa-, “the good luck of (this) favourable birth”.
